author: PrinceLP
body:
I think you are misreading this. It is as the holder's option (means the note holder not Aphria)

 Holders of the Notes may convert all or any portion of their Notes, in multiples of $1 USD principal amount, at their option at any time between December 1, 2023 to the maturity date 

 The Company may not redeem the Notes prior to June 6, 2022, except upon the occurrence of certain changes in tax laws. On or after June 6, 2022, the Company may redeem for cash all or part of the Notes, at its option, if the last reported sale price of the Company’s common shares has been at leas**t 130% of the conversion price then in effect for at least 20 trading days during any 30 consecutive trading day period ending on and including trading day immediately preceding the date won which the Company provide notice of redemption**. The redemption of Notes will be equal to 100% of the principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date.  

APH can redeem if the price is (\~$12 CAD) for 30 days or more after June 2022

APH's cash is a wash with their converts (except the new $100M investment)

body:
I don't see what they have that'd make them pop. WoW classic was baked in back in November when it went from low 50's to upper 50's. People like me who have lives played for 2 months for nostalgia then quit. The subs I follow indicate it's dying except for extremely obese nerds who have been playing since 2004. 

The only thing I can see them having is CoD Battle Royale. They had a teaser with a C-130 dropping people and a gas ring and people are 100% sure (reasonably so) that this is a BR trailer. Combine that with the already high fan base of the new CoD game (myself included) and it  could make them some money.

That being said over 60% of what they earn is from mobile games so that's really where the money is. If there's news I don't know about a new Candy Crush game or something which is their bread and butter then maybe.

I have no idea what this guy thinks is going to make it explode unless he has tunnel vision thinking the ~3 fully populated streamer servers on WoW classic are making them anything more than chump change.

I was long AMD and got in around $17 and again at mid-$30s, got out recently at $48.

Aren't you worried about how poorly Epyc is selling in the datacenter space, especially how they dropped after the last ER (and how Intel skyrocketed after theirs)? Seems everyone is still buying Intel despite a single socket Epyc chip beating out more costly dual socket Xeons configs. Intel is pulling some shady shit too in collaboration with EMC/VMware for licensing per core.

It's like the old saying, "Nobody gets fired for buying IBM."

author: ExceptionallyGreat
body:
No, not worried. These things take time, initial adoption is always slow, but then there is usually the tipping point where things change drastically.

Intel may be involved in deals to undercut their competition on pricing and they may also have long term contracts in place. However, they such things can't go on forever. As more and more companies are moving to the cloud, also cloud business from existing customers is growing by leaps and bound, there is more than enough room for both of them to grow. Along the way, AMD technology will prove it's worth and hopefully grab bigger of server market share.

To your VMWare point, I wasn't aware of it, and it sure is cause for concern. They are by far the largest market shareholder in server virtualisation space, especially for companies who have too much money to throw and are not worried about reducing costs. I will have to look into it further.

I have been buying one AMD share for each $100 I make in a profitable trade. I have accumulating AMD shares this way for a while now.

author: laiod
body:
Stocks paying dividends aren't companies that limit growth. As long as the payout ratio is low and the company has a solid cash flow and business model, I don't see how paying shareholders a dividend is a bad thing.

There's plenty of companies out there paying dividends that consistently increase them every year while also keeping up good growth. Apple, Microsoft, Intel, 3M, and numerous other large companies pay dividends while maintaining the other parts of a good business.

You can't totally disregard dividend stocks. They aren't just using the dividend as leverage to get more shareholders unless they're AT&T and pay a totally unsustainable amount. Everything else has to be factored into the buying decision.

author: nyunaii
body:
Just because 10nm was a huge disaster, doesn't mean 7nm will be. It's a huge effort to develop a node and usually there are 2 parallel developments ongoing with some delay. That means, 7nm is not based 100% on 10nm as one may logically believe.

By the time 7nm development has to make technology choices, the new processes developed for 10nm are often not mature enough and too risky to use, so they would often choose the proven process from 14nm instead. That's why we often see process innovations jump a node. In this case it could be good as the mistakes that were made in 10nm would not be automatically ported to 7nm.
Same thing at TSMC, their 7nm was gold, just like 16nm. 5nm will suck, just like 10nm. And so on, and so on.

So Intel still has a chance of coming out will a brilliant 7nm that will be the industry's first fully-fledged EUV node and taking everyone (here) by surprise. I don't know if they will, I'm just saying they can. As for AMD they do not develop their own semiconductor process, so they are 100% dependent on TSMC.

author: Ancientdollars
body:
Because Intel is a fab company that designs silicon to sell their production capacity. Using old manufacturing technology makes the products they design less competitive which means less revenue and less money to invest into fab tech. They are in a downwards spiral exactly because their strategy is based on the “old ideas” and their organization is too stuck in the past to adapt to the future.

I’m sorry man your just super lost, Intel is not stuck on trying to keep with Moore’s law. They saw the end game of this race long ago and have been adapting their business. Moore’s law was predicted to die by 2025 long ago. They didn’t hear this and just decide to ignore it knowing that they won’t be able to maintain there advantage indefinitely. This is why they have pushed so hard into integration and other areas. 

And despite your uniformed opinion as we have been currently learning over the past two years these integration features matter a lot especially when it comes to industry. As we have seen with NVME drives and data transfer, having correctly  working integrated PCIE lanes can cause a variance in data transfer speeds that range from 20Mbs to 10Gbs. This is literally a gigantic deal.


This all be said, we seem to be going in circles, so thank you for the lively debate but this doesn’t seem to be going anywhere.
